text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have a number of clinical studies uh, that, uh, are in various per deviations of what we could do. Um. So, we || um, have a study of chemotherapy. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Plus vitamin C. That was data that suggest that vitamin C may reduce the side effects from the chemotherapy, may enhance its activity. We don’t know that. That’s a research question. And, so, um then, you are going to go on chemotherapy and are willing to participate, get randomized to get the vitamin C or a dummy infusion. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. That is cumbersome for someone like you. Uh, you’d have to come in at least twice a week to get the vitamin C. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The chemo is every three weeks, but the vitamin C is in high doses and it’s infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, uh, and, as of now, I still think even the placebo equaled yet a dummy infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so, you come in and maybe get tons of sugar. Um. And, we’re trying to sort out side effects of the Docetaxel, and then we can sort of compare it between the two groups --- is, do people have better PSA responses, longer PSA responses or there is no benefit to adding the vitamin C? Patient: Yeah. Okay.

text: Family Member: He definitely has it? Doctor: Right. If it's bad enough where you can't button, your shirt or you're constantly dropping things- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -or you're burning yourself or you're tripping all the time, that- Patient: My neuropathy is xxx. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. And you know, are you are you falling? Patient: No. Doctor: So those are things where it's like, oh, this is bad, but it's a fine line where it could be bad. So we will obsess about how are you doing? You know, is there any change? So, those are one of the things that we would check, but we give the same attention on the trial as well as off the trial. You know, if you're getting this regular chemo anyways, we'd ask you the same obsessive questions- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: How are your feet or your hands. You know what your quality of life, are you losing too much weight, you know, is it too rapid of a weight loss? Are you- you know most people are not nauseous and they don’t throw up, but there's always one in a group you know- are you having problems with that or are your bowels, so we would go down the line like that like we do for Xtandi. And of course now that Xtandi's not working, stop the Xtandi because it's just losses you know kind of drive at the moment, but it's something to consider for later, so we do sometimes go back. Family Member: You're saying Xtandi- Doctor: Mhmm. Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have um two or three uh radiation oncologists here that specialize in that type of therapy for prostate cancer patients. And the other things that are I want to discuss um with you today is a clinical trial – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - where we’re using that type of therapy but instead of not using it and not following um patients and getting data from them, we want learn something from their experience. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And also want to compare the outcomes of patients who get the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately versus those that are observed for a period of time and then we’ll get the stereotactic radiotherapy a little bit later. PAT; Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um the person running the trial is a baseball fan so he has the Oriole trial. Doctor: We call it the Oriole trial. And um basically I will give this consent form and you can take it home to read through. Uh um, ORIOLE basically stands for for observation versus stereotactic radiation therapy for all metastatic prostate cancer. Um, the word means few. Like . And what does metastatic prostate cancer mean a few metastases, so it means few Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: - you are eligible for this type of therapy for this trial. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So in this trial, the ORIOLE part is defined as having three or fewer.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
